image_matrix.caption: The Expedition left Tucma on January 1, 1536. They arrived in Fiambala on January 27. The view is west. In the near distance is the route to San Francisco Pass.
The warm pools of Fiambala are still in existence. Courtesy Flickr.
Upon leaving Fiambala, the Expedition had this view to the west of Cerro Pissis. Courtesy of Sverre Aarseth.
Captain Almagro named the mountains Cordillera San Buenaventura in hopes that the Expedition would be successful. They are now approaching San Francisco Pass.
Expedition members had a view looking west at Incahuasi (21,716') as they approached San Francisco Pass. Courtesy Frosi.jpg.
One of the numerous sources of water on the way to San Francisco Pass. Courtesy Blogspot.
San Francisco Pass is below. The view is west, with Laguna Verde in the near distance. The Expedition crossed the Pass on February 13.
The Expedition camped near a bofedal below San Francisco Pass. This is not that bofedal, but one near Laguna Negro Francisco on the way to Cerro Pissis. R. Villarreal Collection.
The Expedition had a steep climb from Fiambala at 4,938' to the Pass at 15,400'. Courtesy Wikipedia.
A modern-day map of the Great Plateau over which the Almagro Expedition crossed the Great Andes. R. Villarreal Collection.

Laguna Verde (14,200'), looking south. San Francisco Pass is out of sight to the left. Ojos del Salado (22,609' and the second highest peak in the Andes) is in the distance, left of center. The Expedition would have camped all along the south shore of the Laguna. The area experiences high winds most of the year.
Ichu grass is common on the high altiplano and was a favorite of llamas as well as the horses of the Expedition. Courtesy WikiCommons.
A view of the southwestern shore of the Laguna. The view is east. R. Villarreal Collection.
De Mérida received permission from Captain Almagro to approach the great peak, Ojos del Salado, on his own. He quite possibly got this close to view the northern walls. R. Villarreal Collection.

Captain Almagro granted de Mérida's request to inspect Ojos del Salado closer. He says he saw a stream flowing down the side of the peak that emptied into a large sinkhole. It may very well have been a stream like this one, which flows down the northern slopes. R. Villarreal Collection.

The stream was fed by fingers of standing ice higher on the mountain. Here are those \"fingers\", known as nieves penitentes, on the northern slopes of Ojos del Salado. See photos in \"Clawing for the Stars,\" Ch. 1. R. Villarreal Collection.
The Expedition had this as one of the views of Ojos del Salado (in the far distance, center) as they passed it to the north. The view is south. R. Villarreal Collection.

An ojo, a source of water from the underground water table. De Mérida and his party came across one of these on the slopes of Barrancas Blancas. This one is near Monte Pissis, some forty miles south from Ojos del Salado. R. Villarreal Collection.

The Great Plateau stretches some thirty-five miles, at an almost constant elevation of 14,300', from Laguna Verde (behind image, not in view) to Tres Cruces and Rio Lamas Falls. This view is to the west. Ojos del Salado is out of the image, to the left.
Traveling west over the Great Plateau. R. Villarreal Collection.

At the western boundary of the Plateau sits Rio Lamas Falls and, in the mid-distance, Tres Cruces Central (21,743') on the left and Sur (22,133') on the right. The view is south. The wind storm struck the Expedition several miles to the east of this scene. The approximate location of the rock alcove is noted. This is where the soldiers placed three crosses to mark the deaths of their comrades. It is my contention that this event led to the peak being named \"Tres Cruces.\"
Tres Cruces Sur (Central out of view to the left). An alpenglow moment like this one was possibly witnessed by the Expedition members. R. Villarreal Collection.
The men no doubt saw a sunset like this when they were on the Great Plateau.  Sunset from the foot of Tres Cruces.  <span class=\"attribution\">R. Villarreal Collection.<span>
Indian musicians like these played their instruments at the mass for the three dead Spaniards at the foot of Cerro Tres Cruces. Original photogravure, 1931, Atlantis-Verlag. R. Villarreal Collection.

The view is to the west. Note how the Rio Lamas disappears into the sand of the Maricunga Salar in the near distance, just as de Mérida observed. The water surfaces at Flamingo Lake (Laguna Santa Rosa) in the far distance.
At Lamas Falls, guanaco stare at the modern day visitor just as their fore bearers gazed at Expedition members. Chuck Huss Collection.
Flamingo Lake (Laguna Santa Rosa), looking due west. The Expedition no doubt camped around most of the Lake. The date was February 24, 1536.
The Lake is visited daily by flamingos, guanaco, and foxes. The same was the case in 1536. Tres Cruces is capped in clouds in the distance. Chuck Huss Collection.
The Expedition members had this view, excepting the signs! The peaks of Tres Cruces are in the distance. R. Villarreal Collection.
Guanaco are plentiful in this part of the Andes and throughout the Atacama Desert. Courtesy National Geographic.

Cerro Copayapu (Copiapo; 19,855') sits in the middle of the image. Laguna Santa Rosa is a few miles out of sight to the west (right of image). This view is above the approximate location where Captain Almagro, Paullu, and Lieutenant Castilla viewed the peak. Paullu requested that some of the Indians be allowed to climb to the top of the peak to place pieces of wood and stone on a high altar platform there, as an offering to the Sun. The Captain assented. The platform, by the way, actually exists.
This is a view of Cerro Copayapu (Copiapo) from the south, on the banks of Laguna Negro Francisco. R. Villarreal Collection.

This image, and the four following, show several gold mine sites to the south and north of Laguna Santa Rosa. The Spanish did not find gold during their two year journey to Chile. Yet, in a supreme irony, it is plentiful in this and other parts of the country. Mina Marte closed years ago after exhausting its supply of the gold metal.
Mina Maricunga is still in operation. Mina Marte and Laguna Santa Rosa are in the distance.
Mining truck roads at Mina Maricunga. Courtesy of mch cl.jpg.

This gold mine is to the west of Cerro Copiapo, in the center of the image. The author and Patricio drove by it on one trip but we didn't note its name. Mina Marte is to the left and Laguna Negro Francisco is to the upper right.
The same mine, as we drove past it. R. Villarreal Collection.
An abandoned gold mine is in the center of the image. Mina La Coipa is still operating and is to the right. Laguna Santa Rosa is to the left.
Mina La Coipa, still in operation. Courtesy of womp-int.
Back at Laguna Santa Rosa. The expedition is ready for the journey to Copayapu. The view is west.
The scene is just past the pass to the west of Santa Rosa.
An oasis, one of several, on the way to Copayapu.
Another oasis, farther along the road. R. Villarreal Collection.
The Almagro Expedition reached Copayapu (Copiapo) in late summer (March) of 1536.
The Copiapo Cathedral sits on the main square of the city, Plaza Prat. Courtesy Turistel Chile.

The locations of two gold mines outside Copiapo. The infamous San Jose mine, 28 miles from the city, was the site of the October, 2010 rescue of the \"Los 33,\" the 33 miners trapped underground for 69 days.

image_matrix.caption: Antique print, titled: 'Chili.' - This map shows Chili. A very attractive map covering the known coastal region of Chile. The map is based on the cartography of Hessel Gerritsz with north oriented to the left although the compass rose incorrectly depicts north at top. The Andes are shown prominently, with two live volcanoes in the vicinity of Villarrica. San Juan is shown on a large spurious lake east of the Andes and incorrectly located south of Mendoza. The map is very decorative with a large scene of industrious natives and cherubs filling the entire top of the map. The ocean is embellished with two galleons and a compass rose. Description: From: 'De Nieuwe en Onbekende Weereld: of beschryving van America en 't Zuid-Land.', by Arnoldus Montanus, published in Amsterdam by Jacob van Meurs in 1671. (The New and Unknown World: or Description of America and the Southland, Containing the Origin of the Americans and South-landers, remarkable voyages thither, Quality of the Shores, Islands, Cities, Fortresses, Towns, Temples, Mountains, Sources, Rivers, Houses, the nature of Beasts, Trees, Plants and foreign Crops, Religion and Manners, Miraculous Occurrences, Old and New Wars: Adorned with Illustrations drawn from the life in America, and described by Arnoldus Montanus). The book was translated and published in England by the editor and map publisher John Ogilby under the title, America, Being an Accurate Description of the New World (1671). Ref: In the late 1630s, Holland attempted to reassert its claim over Brazil by establishing a series of forts along the coastline. One of the best-documented colonies was the expedition led by Prince Maurits of Nassau, who attempted to assemble an intellectual court in the New World. He brought with him a group of highly accomplished artists, mapmakers, and scientists to record the mysteries of Brazil. They included the celebrated painter Frans Post, and the astronomer George Markgraf, who produced the first serious study of the southern sky. R. Villarreal Collection.
On the way from Laguna Santa Rosa to Copayapu the scenery was exactly as appears here. Original 1906 halftone print by Dodd, Mead and Company of a Trans-Andean Chile valley. R. Villarreal Collection.
A recent photo of Copiapo's main plaza. The Expedition arrived in the village of Copayapu on March 11, 1536 and prepared to journey south in search of gold. Courtesy skyscraperlife.com.
Father Molina celebrates the first mass in Chile in the town of Copayapu on March 12, 1536. HistChile.
The mystery of the sea shell jewelry de Mérida observed in Tucma was solved in Copayapu. These ornaments were made in the town for local purchase and for trade with Tucma. Courtesy delsshells.
The Blooming of the Desert outside Copiapo, an event that takes place only every six to eight years. De Mérida makes mention of the phenomenon. Courtesy photographersdirect.com.

Hovering above Lake Titicaca, Bolivia, looking south. In this part of the Letter, de Mérida quotes Garcilasso de la Vega as to how the Inca conquered Chile. Three Inca armies invaded the country in the 1470's. From present-day Titicaca, they struck southwest and entered Chile in the northern Atacama Desert.
After leaving Lake Titicaca, the armies marched through the village of Tupiza.
Today's Tupiza, Bolivia. Courtesy blogspot.
Inca Yupanqui, the ruler who ordered the conquest of Chile. Courtesy of fotosyimagenes.
A chart showing how the Inca ordered their army ranks. Courtesy of Wikipedia.
The following pictures will identify the water sources probably used by the Inca armies on their way to and through Chile. Laguna Pozuelo is south of the town of Tupiza. Courtesy estolugares.
Laguna de Vilama is below and southwest of Laguna Pozuelo. Courtesy proclamadelcauca2.
Farther south from Vilama, Laguna Azufrera offered another source for the Inca soldiers. Courtesy panoramio.
Continuing southwest, Laguna Honda presents another possibility for water. It is close to the Tatio geysers. Courtesy minakov.
The armies probably passed the Tatio geyser basin on their way southwest to the Atacama region. This was another source of water.
An erupting geyser on the basin today. Courtesy of normadruss.
The ruins of an Inca tambo at Catarpe, an Inca administrative center just north of San Pedro de Atacama. Courtesy Atacamachile.com.
A view above San Pedro de Atacama, with Angastu to the right and Llullaillaco in the distance to the left. Copayapu is directly south.
A small plaza in today's San Pedro de Atacama. Courtesy of Wikicom.
Vestiges of an Inca road through the Atacama Desert. From John Hyslop's \"The Inka Road System.\"

As the Inca armies continued south from San Pedro in their conquest of Chile, they would have come across small villages and more water sources. This is a small hotel in the old mining town of Socaire. Courtesy danlmarmot.
Laguna Misconti provides water for the residents of Socaire and nearby Peine and would have been a prime source for the Inca armies. Courtesy maccosta.
The small mining village of Peine was also on the route of the armies. Courtesy Salzman.

A view of the northern slopes of the peak Llullaillaco. The mountain is south of Peine. The armies would have passed it to the west (to the right) on their way south. There are several streams, like the one pictured, that flow from the peak's snow fields. R. Villarreal Collection.

A view of Laguna Aguas Calientes, which rests southwest of Llullaillaco. This served as yet another place for the armies to refresh their water supplies. See the author's book Clawing for the Stars for his visits to this mountain. R. Villarreal Collection.
South from Laguna Aguas Calientes, among many small lakes along the way, lies the Salar de la Isla. Courtesy discoveryconsultants.
Southwest from de la Isla and on the way to Copayapu, Salar de Infieles provided another water source for the Inca armies. Courtesy mw1google.
Nearing Copayapu, the Salar de Pedernales offered yet another source. Courtesy pbase.

This is a Google Earth image of the valley of Chile. Modern day Santiago is to the left. De Mérida quotes from a letter he received from the Inca historian Garcilasso de la Vega about the Inca armies as they pushed south from Copayapu: \"Thence they advanced, subduing all the nations as far as the valley of Chile, from which the whole country took its name. While this conquest took place, which is said to have lasted more than six years, . . .\" So conquering the middle part of Chile was not an easy task.
A scene from the northern reaches of the Valley of Chile looking east. The peak in the distance is probably Tupungato. Courtesy blogfriendsheet.com.
Not satisfied with their conquests of Chile down to the Valley, the Inca decided to press on, until reaching the Maule River 155 miles to the south.

The Inca armies pressed across the Maule, only to be turned back by the fierce Araucanian people. As Garcilasso writes: \"At this point, it seemed to the Inca that it would be more in keeping with the policy of their kings to give way to the bestial fury of their enemies than to destroy them with the object of subjugation. And so they resolved to return to the country already conquered and fix the river Maule as the boundary of their empire.\" Courtesy trekkingchile.com.

The town of Vallenar (called Huasco in de Merida's day). The Expedition fought a tough battle on the approach to this small farming and mining town in the Huasco River Valley.
Possibly one of the Battle of Huasco bridges looked similar to this one. Courtesy dosmanos.com.
A modern-day view of Huasco (today's Vallenar). Courtesy of fotopaises.
The Expedition encountered bee-hives on the outskirts of Cuquimpu. Those men who indulged themselves with the honey inside became seriously ill for 24 hours. Courtesy of enjoy-chile.org.
La Serena and Cuquimpu, looking south.
Cuquimpu today. Outside Cuquimpu/La Serena occurred the \"honey\" incident. Courtesy of UkrainianGirlAbroad.com.
A La Serena beach scene today. The city and its beaches are a favorite tourist attraction. Courtesy of chile1mas1.
At the seaside villages of La Serena and Cuquimpu, de Merida tells of the numerous reed hats worn by the townspeople. Courtesy of dbaoracle.com.
While in Cuquimpu, Captain Alvarado and his men proceeded up the Elqui River valley looking for concealed gold.
The Elqui river runs its course through the valley. Courtesy of manvschile.
A view west towards the reservoir, the source of the Elqui River.
A view of the Puclaro Dam today. Captain Alvarado marveled at the structure in place in his day. Courtesy of FranFiondella.
The physical location of Ovalle, known as Limari in de Merida's time.
Ovalle is watered by melting snow on the mountains to the east. Courtesy of flickriver.com.

1H-K3 Women's jewelry. The stones on the right are the \"Inca's stone,\" sodalite. Expedition members acquired small bags of these stones in today's Oruro, Bolivia, to use as barter for food the rest of the expedition The stones on the left are lapis lazuli. It is mined in southern Chile outside present day Ovalle, Chile (known as Limari at the time of the expedition's passage). The soldiers also used this stone for bartering.R. Villarreal Collection.
The dam and reservoir of La Paloma, situated several miles to the southeast of present day Ovalle (Limari in de Mérida's day). Courtesy stanito.com.
Google Earth image of the Illapel valley. The town is north of Papudo.

Today's Illapel, with a population of 33,000. This is where the men saw the mysterious jumping animals (probably chinchilla). The townspeople used their fur to make warm clothing. The town today maintains the National Reserve for Chinchillas for their protection. Courtesy Wikipedia.
The jumping chinchillas of Illapel. Courtesy trekkingchile.com.
Small Indian village near the town of Illapel. Original 1841 lithograph of a central Chile village. Creator: R. B. Seeley and W. Burnside. R. Villarreal Collection.

A 1932 photograph of possibly the Elqui or Limari valleys looking towards the Pacific. It was taken by a pilot of the Pan American Airway System flying south to Santiago de Chile. Publisher: Fortune Magazine. R. Villarreal Collection.

A favored activity in Papudo is riding horseback on the beaches. Courtesy of balnearios10.com.
A condor soars above the Andean foothills. De Mérida and Father Molina discoursed here in Papudo about their encounters over the years with the giant bird. Courtesy of svcalypso.com.

Depictions of Indian warriors at the Battle of Papudo. Years later, de Mérida observed that they could only have been the battle-hardened Araucanian Indians, descendants of those who held off the Inca armies several decades before. Courtesy missouristate.edu.
A 1912 original print of an Araucanian Indian on horseback. Artist: Archibald Stevenson Forrest. Publisher: A&C Black. R. Villarreal Collection.
Battle instruments such as these no doubt were used in the Battle of Papudo, by both sides. Courtesy of outpost.org.
Spiked clubs like this one were common weapons used by Inca soldiers. Courtesy of Incadigital.

De Mérida mentions that the Indians played haunting music with flutes and stringed instruments at the mass for Francisco de Vald�s. The pictured instruments must be close in design to those used centuries ago. Courtesy of Incablog.
This a reasonable likeness of the Santiaguillo, the ship that met the Almagro Expedition at Cuquimpu. Courtesy of Pixabay

The men on board the Santiago brought news that Manco Inca and his forces were laying siege to Cuzco. De Mérida knew that this would end the Spanish search for gold in Chile since Almagro's force would be needed for the fight. Courtesy Wikimedia.

Antique print, titled: 'Chili.' - This map shows Chili. A very attractive map covering the known coastal region of Chile. The map is based on the cartography of Hessel Gerritsz with north oriented to the left although the compass rose incorrectly depicts north at top. The Andes are shown prominently, with two live volcanoes in the vicinity of Villarrica. San Juan is shown on a large spurious lake east of the Andes and incorrectly located south of Mendoza. The map is very decorative with a large scene of industrious natives and cherubs filling the entire top of the map. The ocean is embellished with two galleons and a compass rose. Description: From: 'De Nieuwe en Onbekende Weereld: of beschryving van America en 't Zuid-Land.', by Arnoldus Montanus, published in Amsterdam by Jacob van Meurs in 1671. (The New and Unknown World: or Description of America and the Southland, Containing the Origin of the Americans and South-landers, remarkable voyages thither, Quality of the Shores, Islands, Cities, Fortresses, Towns, Temples, Mountains, Sources, Rivers, Houses, the nature of Beasts, Trees, Plants and foreign Crops, Religion and Manners, Miraculous Occurrences, Old and New Wars: Adorned with Illustrations drawn from the life in America, and described by Arnoldus Montanus). The book was translated and published in England by the editor and map publisher John Ogilby under the title, America, Being an Accurate Description of the New World (1671). Ref: In the late 1630s, Holland attempted to reassert its claim over Brazil by establishing a series of forts along the coastline. One of the best-documented colonies was the expedition led by Prince Maurits of Nassau, who attempted to assemble an intellectual court in the New World. He brought with him a group of highly accomplished artists, mapmakers, and scientists to record the mysteries of Brazil. They included the celebrated painter Frans Post, and the astronomer George Markgraf, who produced the first serious study of the southern sky. R. Villarreal Collection.
Today's Copiapo. The Cathedral of Our Lady of the Rosary is to the left. Fringes of the main Plaza, Plaza Prat, are to the right. Courtesy of descubreatacama.

One of the lush valleys on the outskirts of Copiapo. Grapes are the main crop and, on a smaller scale, olives, tomatoes, peppers, onions, broad beans, citrus fruits, nectarines, apricots, oregano, and flowers. Courtesy of viajeschile.
Natives of Copayapu play cup and ball. 1875 Wood Engraving by Edouard Riou. Publisher: Scribner, Armstrong. R. Villarreal Collection.
The expedition left Copayapu and turned to the north below the water source of San Andres. Farther north is the Salar de Pedernales. Google Earth imagery.
The road east of Copayapu near the point where the expedition struck out north for the return to Peru. R. Villarreal Collection.
The first major source of water after leaving Copayapu was the Salar de Pedernales. Volcan Doña Inéz is noted. Google Earth imagery.
Flamingos on the Laguna Pedernales. Courtesy of confort.cl.
Volcan Doña Inéz, on the left, on the northwestern side of the Salar de Pedernales. Courtesy: Panoramio.com
An Atacama Desert lizard. De Mérida says that Yupan was adept at capturing these small creatures and skinning them. Courtesy: Atacamaphoto.
An Atacama fox feasts on a guanaco. Courtesy: en.wikipedia.
An Atacama guanaco gazes at a visitor. Courtesy: geovitual2.
The Captain leads the expedition somewhere between Copayapu and Atacama. Courtesy: cacordova weekly.
The expedition passed by the Salars of Infieles and de Aguilar which lie north of the Pedernales. Google Earth imagery.
A modern photo of Laguna Infieles. Courtesy atacamapano.
Laguna de Aguilar. Courtesy of Panoramio.
More Lagunas the expedition passed. These are to the north of Laguna de Aguilar. Google imagery.
Photo of Laguna Gorbea. Courtesy of taringa.net.

Google imagery of Volcan Lastarria with Laguna de las Azufrera to the immediate north and Aguas Calientes (the \"Laguna of the White Sands,\" as de Mérida called it) to the left. In the distance is Llullaillaco.
The northern aspect of Lastarria, the faintly smoking mountain. R. Villarreal Collection.
The eastern view of Lastarria. The expedition passed it on its western side. R. Villarreal Collection.
Laguna Azufrera 1, at the northern foot of Lastarria. Courtesy of worldmaps.com.

Laguna Aguas Calientes (Captain Almagro's Laguna of the White Sands). This is a view of the approach from the west. The expedition approached it from the right, or from the south. R. Villarreal Collection.

The northwest portion of Aguas Calientes (Almagro's Laguna of the White Sands). Notice the stone walls left of center that might have served as part of the enclosures for the guanaco encirclement. R. Villarreal Collection.
The southern reaches of Aguas Calientes (Almagro's Laguna of the White Sands), looking southeast. R. Villarreal Collection.
A brilliant alpenglow bathes the mountain, Llullaillaco, at sunset. No doubt the expedition saw just such a sight during their stay at Aguas Calientes. R. Villarreal Collection.
The expedition passed to the west of the great mountain on their way north and would have seen this view of the northern walls. R. Villarreal Collection.

The site of today's Mina Escondida, the largest open pit copper mine in the world. It sits 12-15 miles to the west of Llullaillaco. The expedition passed close to it, not knowing of its future eminence in the copper mining industry. Google imagery.

The view south with the train station of Monturaqui (below) and the barely in view summit of Llullaillaco some 14 miles in the distance. The expedition found Inca storehouses here with supplies for the high priest in Calama and his priests for their journey to the mountain to offer sacrifices. Google imagery.
The ruins of one of the storehouses. Google imagery.
Another storehouse ruin. Google imagery.
North from Monturaqui, the expedition came upon the small villages, Peine and Socaire, and the large laguna, Miscanti. Google image.
The small village of Peine. The local inhabitants are dedicated to the production of lithium. Courtesy of nma,gov.au.
In Peine, the ruins of an Inca pukara, or fortress. Courtesy of sanpedrochile.com.
Present-day Socaire, which lies several miles northeast from Peine. Courtesy of chiletravel.
Laguna Miscanti, which rests a few miles to the east of Socaire. Courtesy of wikimedia.
Proceeding north, the expedition passed Laguna Chaxa, a part of the Chilean Federal Flamingo Reserve below San Pedro de Atacama. Courtesy of Manuela Paissan.
Flamingoes on Laguna Chaxa. Courtesy of santiagoadventures.
Laguna Tebinquinche, north of Chaxa and part of the Flamingo Reserve. Courtesy of tripadvisor.
Flamingoes in flight. R. Villarreal Collection.
Street scene in Toconao, south of Atacama. The expedition bypassed this settlement because some villagers were sick with fever and nausea. Courtesy of panoramio.com.
The expedition camped at a laguna just to the south of Atacama village. It must have been this one -- Laguna Cejar. Courtesy of andestropicales.org.
The landscape to the south of Atacama. Google imagery.
Street scene in present-day San Pedro de Atacama. Courtesy of plataformaurbana.
Another street photo in San Pedro. Courtesy of plataformaurbana.
Volcan Licancabor as seen from San Pedro de Atacama. Courtesy of wikipedia.org.

De Mérida and Ancohualla met Apani in Atacama (today's San Pedro de Atacama) and heard his story of how the Indians built the huts on the summit of Llullaillaco. A modern-day street scene in this charming town. Courtesy of visitchile.com.

Angastu (Antofagasta) was the jump-off point for Llullaillaco. We can only infer from the information presented in the recording of the conversation with Apani that the effort to place huts on the summit of the peak began in late August 1494.
Today's Antofagasta is a bustling port city of 345,000 people. Courtesy of misionlatinoamericana.
It really does snow in the Atacama Desert! Courtesy aljazeera.com. Also, see Chapter 6, Clawing for the Stars, for the author's experiences with Atacama snow storms.
A source of water on the way to Monturaqui.
And another.
This was the supply location for men, goods, and equipment on their way to Llullaillaco. The summit of the peak is just in view to the south.
This is one of several building ruins next to Monturaqui. These no doubt go back to the time of Apani.
A water source on the way from Monturaqui to the western side of the mountain.

The northern end of Laguna Aguas Calientes, which sits below the western side of the peak. Vitahuati and his men had first planned to climb to the summit by way of the western walls. R. Villarreal Collection.
This area would have served well as a Base Camp on the western side for Vita and his men. R. Villarreal Collection.
This area would have made a good first camp site, at 16,500', for the cunturs as they labored up the western slopes. R. Villarreal Collection.
This spot, at 18,300', might have served the cunturs well as the next higher camp on the western side. R. Villarreal Collection.
This is the plateau, at 19,300', where Apani said the cunturs realized the western side was too steep from here to the summit and chose to turn around and descend. R. Villarreal Collection.

Vitahuati and his men decided to search for a suitable route to the summit somewhere else on the peak. No doubt they had a similar view of the northern slopes on their way around the mountain, as pictured here. R. Villarreal Collection.
Vitahuati and the cunturs led the traverse past these northwest walls in search of a route to the top. R. Villarreal Collection.
Flowing water north of Llullaillaco. Courtesy of Wikimedia.com.
The eastern side of Llullaillaco, with the ascent route of the Indians in the middle of the picture (see following Google Earth images for details). Courtesy of Johan Reinhard.
Google Earth image showing the positions of the staging area and Main Camp.
Image showing the location of First Camp and Second Camp.
This structure, along with several others not in the picture, mark the location of Vitahuati's main camp area at 17,056'. Courtesy of Johan Reinhard.
At an elevation of 19,188', this was the location of first camp for the climbers and builders. Courtesy of Johan Reinhard.
This area was the second camp for the men, at an elevation of 21,800', just below the summit. Courtesy of Johan Reinhard.
Johan Reinhard and his team of archaeologists examine the huts and graves on the summit at 22,109'. Courtesy of Joan Reinhard.
A look down upon the huts. Courtesy Chuck Huss Collection.
The Reinhard team surveys more of the summit ruins. Courtesy of Johan Reinhard.

This is the small Inca fortress of Catarpe. It lies just outside of the village of Atacama on the way to Calama. There are several of these on the route of the Expedition. They were originally built to support the Inca troops invading Chile in the late 15th century. Courtesy of viajeschile.com.
1875 Original Engraving of an Inca Pukara or Fortress. Artist: Edouard Riou. Publisher: Scribner, Armstrong, & Co. R. Villarreal Collection.
On the march from Atacama to Calama, de Merida remarks upon the wide variety of cacti growing in the Atacama desert. No doubt this particular variety existed in his day. Courtesy of atacamaphoto.com.
Here is another example of an Atacama Desert cactus. Courtesy of atacamaphoto.com.
An additional one. Courtesy of elevenshadows.com.
And a different one. Courtesy of atacamaphoto.com.

View of Calama. This is where the Desert Cacique, Huaman, ruled the town and the surrounding villages. He made a deep impression upon Captain Almagro, so much so that he signed a parchment to the effect that Huaman would serve as governor of this area for the Captain (Almagro had been awarded Chile by the King of Spain). Courtesy of esacademic.com.

Copper pots from Calama. The area surrounding Calama is noted for its copper mines. The author purchased these pots made in the city at the Santiago airport during the years of his travels. R. Villarreal Collection.
Original 1922 half-tone print of a copper mine outside Calama. Publisher: National Geographic. R. Villarreal Collection.
Eastern terrain outside Calama looking towards the nearby Andean peaks. Courtesy of wordpress.
Google Earth view of the Calama, Chiu-Chiu area.

Chuquicamata copper mine outside Calama. It's the second largest open pit mine in Chile, after Mina Escondida. When the author took the mine tour in the early '90s, the depth of the hole was truly impressive. When the Expedition passed through this area, their smithies used copper to fashion horseshoes for the horsemen. Courtesy of followtheblog.
One of the mine's huge dump trucks. The wheels are 13 feet high! Courtesy of gonback.com.
Chiu-Chiu street scene today. The men stayed two days here and were treated well by the cacique. Courtesy of rutaschile.com.
The Lasana fortress outside Chiu-Chiu. This was another of the Inca pukaras built to serve the Inca armies passing through. Courtesy of municipalidadcalama.com.

image_matrix.caption: The Conchi Reservoir which provides water for Chuquicamata mine. Courtesy of flickr.com.
The Expedition is now on the Avenue of the Volcáns. This is a photo of the twin active volcanoes, San Pedro (20,161') on the right and San Pablo (19,981') on the left. Courtesy of semageomin.cl.
Close to the twin volcanoes is another active volcano, Paniri (19,554'). Courtesy of pano.com.
Since leaving Calama, the Expedition followed the Loa River north. It is Chile's longest, with a length of 273 miles. Courtesy of fotonaturleza.
Another view of the Loa River, with Avenue volcanoes to the northeast. Courtesy of tomasmunita.com.
This image is at the southern reaches of the Avenue of the Volcanoes, looking north. The Rio Loa is on the left. The Expedition relied upon its waters for several weeks. Google Earth image.
Somewhere along the Avenue of the Volcáns. Original half-tone print, 1906. Publisher: J. B. Lippincott Company. R. Villarreal Collection.
Continuing north, the men passed the active volcano, Palpana, (19,755'). Courtesy of andes.org.uk.
They passed more active volcanoes, this one is Aucanquilcha (20,262'). Courtesy of pano.com.
Right next to Aucanquilcha is another active volcano, Miño (18,568'). This peak is the source of the River Loa. Courtesy of pano.com.

Two days after passing Miño, they came upon the active volcano, Irruputuncu (16,939'). This area is where horseman Mejia was thrown from his horse and the unfortunate aftermath events transpired. Courtesy of chileviaje.com.
Google Earth image of the Salar Coposa, looking north, where Horseman Mejia lost his life. Volcan Irruputuncu is at the lower right.
De Mérida tells of coming upon several water fountains after leaving Irruputuncu. This was the geyser field of Puchuldiza. Courtesy of canalblog.com.
One day's march from the geyser field, the men came upon another active volcano, Isluga (18,204'). Courtesy of flickr.
Somewhere on the Avenue, many years after the Expedition passed over it. 1888 original wood engraving. Publisher: Harper & Brothers. R. Villarreal Collection.
Once beyond Isluga, they encounter the active volcano, Arintica (18,362')). Courtesy of mountainforecast.com.
They finally encounter the mighty Guallatiri (19,918'). It's name comes from the Aymara and means \"sewn together by rocks.\" Plumes of smoke and steam rose from its summit. Courtesy of turichile.
Google Earth view of today's Vicuña Reserve and Volcán Guallatiri. This is the place where Diegito and his friends conducted a vicuña hunt with bolas.

Another photo of Guallatiri. This is the area where Diegito and his friends tried to capture a vicuña using Indian bolas, with humorous results. Today, these lands are part of a vast Chilean Vicuña reserve. Courtesy of skimountaineer.com.
The camelid family. The Expedition now had encountered each one at some point on their journey. Courtesy of llamalocater.com.

image_matrix.caption: Photo of the Indian bolas used by Diegitio and his friends. Courtesy of slinging.org.
Upon leaving the Guallatiri area, if the men looked to the northeast, they would have seen Parinacota (20,827'), with Pomerape (20,610') right behind it. Courtesy of pano.com.

The town of Putre nestles near the two summits of Taapaca, the higher of which, on the right, is 19,220'. Now nearing Peru, the Expedition was vigilant to possible attacks from Inca soldiers. Courtesy of mountainphotos.com.
Today's Tacna, Peru. The Expedition reached the village in late February, 1537. Courtesy of capital.com.pe.

The Expedition did not enter Arica, Chile, which is only 35 miles south from Tacna. They were eager to return to Peru and Cuzco. 1901 original half-tone print of the Morro de Arica. Publisher: Edward Stanford. R. Villarreal Collection.
There are several copper mines in the Tacna area. Here is one of them, the Toquepala Mine. Courtesy of chicop.com.
Today's Tacna, Peru. Captain Almagro sent Lt. Montesinos and several men from here on to Moquegua to find Captain Orgoñez and learn the situation in Cuzco. Courtesy of no.wikipedia.com.
Today's Plaza de Armas in Tacna. The famed Gustave Eiffel designed the San Pedro de Tacna church in the background in 1875. Courtesy of sumaqperu.com

A large outdoor marketplace in Tacna today. A cacique led the men through what was called the great qhatu (Aymara for marketplace), a market similar to a giant Wal-Mart today! Courtesy of gotsaga.com.
The produce section of the great qhatu probably looked something like this Tacna market display. Courtesy of pe.com.
Today's Locumba Valley, rich in farmland. The Expedition passed through here on the way to Moquegua. Courtesy of pe.com.
This Google Earth image hovers above Tacna, Peru, with the Locumba Valley to the north and Moquegua farther in the distance.  This was the route of the Expedition on their way to Arequipa.
The Mina Toquepala, a large copper mine near Moquegua. Courtesy of larepublica.pe.

Today's Moquegua. The Expedition passed through here on the way to Vitor. The town enjoys the distinction that the famed Gustave Eiffel designed its Plaza de Armas in the late 19th century. Courtesy of sindramas.com.
Ornamental Fountain of the Three Graces at night in Moquegua, designed by Gustave Eiffel in 1877. Courtesy of shandee1blogspot.

After leaving Moquegua, Expedition members may have seen Cerro Ubinas (18,609 ft) on the way to Vitor and Arequipa. 1933 Original Halftone Print of Mt. Ubinas. Publisher: National Geographic Magazine. R. Villarreal Collection.
On the journey from Moquegua to Vitor, de Mérida comments upon the cactus plants of southern Peru. Here are some present-day examples. Courtesy of all-peru.com.
Here are more cacti of southern Peru. Courtesy of fairtravel4u.org.
The approach to Arequipa from the farming community of Vitor. Nevado Chachani (19,872 feet) is in the distance. Soon the battle for Fortress Arequipa would commence. Courtesy of flickriver.com.
The port and village of Ilay to the west of Arequipa. 1875 Original Wood Engraving. Creator: Scribner, Armstrong, & Co. R. Villarreal Collection.
Arequipa, with El Misti in the distance. 1888 Original Wood Engraving. Creator: Harper & Brothers. R. Villarreal Collection.
The village of Sachaca. Today it is one of several Arequipa suburbs and lies within the city's limits. 1875 Original Wood Engraving. Creator: Scribner, Armstrong. R. Villarreal Collection.

These are the ruins of the Inca fortress of Sacsayhuaman outside Cuzco, Peru. Archaeologists believe that Fortress Arequipa was of a similar size and extent. Over the centuries, however, earthquakes have shaken the Arequipa area and dislodged most of the large stones. The villagers then used them to build structures in town. Courtesy southeastco.uk Also, see the Glanzman painting of fighting before the Fortress, P3.3 on the site.
Stone wall of the Sacsayhuaman Fortress. This offers an example of what the Fortress Arequipa walls would have looked like. R. Villarreal Collection.

The Rio Chili runs through Arequipa. (Chili in Aymara means \"rattle,\" for the sound stones make as the river pushes them over its bed.) El Misti is in the distance. The once proud Inca fortress lay a short distance from the river. Courtesy of pano.com.
Google Earth view of Arequipa looking east to El Misti.
1875 Original Wood Engraving of an Arequipa lady in full dress. Creator: Scribner, Armstrong, & Co. R. Villarreal Collection.
1875 Original Wood Engraving of housetops in old Arequipa. Creator: Scribner, Armstrong, & Co. R. Villarreal Collection.
Old Inca aqueduct in the countryside near Arequipa. Courtesy of travelsickness.com.
1927 Original Halftone Print of Arequipa, with El Misti in the distance. Creator: Charles Scribner's Sons. R. Villarreal Collection.

1875 Original Wood Engraving of San Francisco Street in Arequipa. This is the old historic center of the city. The buildings are made of sillar (white volcanic stones) rock. The stone has been used in many parts of the city and has prompted it to be called the \"White City.\" Artist: Edouard Riou. Publisher: Scribner, Armstrong, & Co.R. Villarreal Collection.

Scene of a courtyard in the large nunnery of Santa Catalina in Arequipa.  Construction began in the late 1500's.  It remained a mystery, except to the nuns there, until 1970 when they opened it for public visitation.  Note that El Misti volcano rises in the distance.  My wife and I toured the nunnery on our tour of Peru in 1975.  <span class=\"attribution\">Courtesy of Kiara Gallop.
View of the Orange Cloister of Santa Catalina. The entire nunnery is constructed with sillar, the volcanic stone of Arequipa. Courtesy of Kiara Gallop.

Probable site of Fortress Arequipa. The Rio Chili is in view at the bottom with walls and terracing in the picture's middle. Arequipa is behind, with El Misti in the distance. Courtesy of en.wikipedia.com.

When the Indian cacique, Huanca, who is leading the fight against the Spanish from a Fortress Arequipa tower, sees his brother beheaded, he realizes the fight is over and jumps 200 feet to his death. Artist: Everett Gee Jackson.
The \"Buried Valley\" near old Arequipa. 1927 Original Halftone Print. Creator: Charles Scribner's Sons. R. Villarreal Collection.
River rafting on the Chili is very popular. Here a boatload try their hand at it. It's not anything like going down the Colorado, but what other river is? Courtesy of giardinotours.com.

Antique print, titled: 'Chili.' - This map shows Chili. A very attractive map covering the known coastal region of Chile. The map is based on the cartography of Hessel Gerritsz with north oriented to the left although the compass rose incorrectly depicts north at top. The Andes are shown prominently, with two live volcanoes in the vicinity of Villarrica. San Juan is shown on a large spurious lake east of the Andes and incorrectly located south of Mendoza. The map is very decorative with a large scene of industrious natives and cherubs filling the entire top of the map. The ocean is embellished with two galleons and a compass rose. They included the celebrated painter Frans Post, and the astronomer George Markgraf, who produced the first serious study of the southern sky. R. Villarreal Collection.

De Mérida mentions passing an irrigation canal of a unique design after passing through Andahuaylillas. Perhaps it was similar to this one, located near their route of march. Courtesy: greenperuadventures.

As they neared Raqch'i, a temple and storage complex, de Mérida says that for some distance they followed an Inca road with a roadbed of finely shaped stones. Here is an example of one such road. Courtesy: commonswikimedia.

This is a photo of much of the Raqch'i complex that still survives today. It lies some 60 miles south of Cuzco and 50 miles north from Juliaca. To quote de Mérida from the Fourth Letter: \"Ancohualla described it thus: It served as a control point on the road between Cuzco and the towns to the south, such as Puno. A three mile perimeter wall encircled several Inca buildings. On the other side of this wall, an enclosure with eight rectangular buildings around a bright courtyard served as a welcoming place for travelers, with lodging for the people and stables for llamas. Anco continued that different areas served different functions – one to house troops, others for conducting religious festivities, still more were food and supply warehouses. The irrigated terraces on nearby hillsides testified to the agricultural richness of this place. A nearby warm spring fed water to a pool for cleansing the body. A large temple, one obviously for religious rites, completed the scene before us.\" Photo courtesy of: taringa.net.
This is part of the remaining walls of the Temple of Viracocha. Courtesy of peruadventuretours.
More Raqch'i walls. Courtesy of albumfotos.com.
More remnants of the Viracocha Temple. Somewhere within the Raqch'i complex, Gómez de Almagro was thrown from his horse and died of severe head wounds. Courtesy: Perutravel.
Original 1875 Wood Engraving of the Viracocha Temple amongst the Raqch'i ruins. Creator: Scribner, Armstrong, & Co. Artist: Edouard Riou. R. Villarreal Collection.

This village, called Hullaqa in de Mérida’s day (today known as Juliaca), the Expedition passed through in February, 1540. The natives made and marketed all types of warm clothing that the men bartered for to prepare for the coming cold days. Because of today's production of this clothing, it is also known as \"Sock City\" and \"Knitting City.\" It sits at 12,549 feet and has 225,000 citizens today. Courtesy of en.wikipedia
Caption: De Mérida called this \"a small, unremarkable village called Puno.\" Today it has 150,000 citizens and lies at 12,556 feet. Courtesy of Fotos de Puno.
The view of the eastern shore of Lake Titicaca from the towns on its western shores. Courtesy topvisitplaces.
Caption: A bustling market in today's Puno. Courtesy of Perutravel.

Ilave, at 12,621 feet and with 54,000 citizens, is south from Puno and bordered by the Ilave River, which the Expedition will follow to the west towards Putre for more than half the way. Courtesy of pano.com.
Another photo of Ilave. Courtesy of worldmapz.com.
A Google Earth image of the small village of Siraya.
Siraya, in de Mérida’s time and still so today, is a small village two days march west from Ilave. Its population is 900 inhabitants. Courtesy of joseluis379Pano.

Cachuma. West from Siraya lies the small settlement of Cachuma. Here is where de Merida mentions the Indian woman, Pilca Huaca. Doña Inéz had asked Valdivia for a medical assistant and Ancohualla suggested this woman, who happened to be an Inca princess. La Doña had already met her and was delighted that she would assist her. Courtesy of Jose Luis379.
Mazo Cruz. This is another small settlement, this one sits west from Cachuma. Courtesy of elcomercio.com.

Visviri. From this area, Lt. Montesinos saw the peak Taapaca to the west, which sits just outside Putre. Today, this town maintains the border station between Chile and Bolivia. Courtesy of Elias Munoz

Pukará de Copaquilla. This Inca fort/storage site is south from Visviri. Ancohualla said that the third Inca army to invade Chile passed this way and used this place to resupply themselves with food the local villagers had stored there. Courtesy of Wikimediacommons.

Pomerape, Parinacota. These two strato-volcanoes soon came in view. Pomerape, at 20,610 feet, is in front, with Parinacota, at 20,827 feet, to the left and behind it. They are known as the “Payachatas”, or fraternal twins in Aymara. Courtesy of Claudio Solari.
A Google Earth view of Pomerape and Parinacota, looking south.

Jurasi. This is the Jurasi thermal basin and springs which lie some six miles to the east of Putre. There are no active geysers today, but the thermal hot springs are a favorite with tourists. The Expedition stayed here for a night. Courtesy of Panoramio.
Taapaca. The mountain Taapaca, 19,230 feet high, sits a few miles to the east of Putre. Courtesy of Octavio Aldea.
Putre and Taapaca. Today's Putre. Courtesy of Travelblog.org.
One of the men from Tacna, Rodrigo Hidalgo, possessed jester skills. The Indians called him Qamchu, which in Quechua means \"one who makes people laugh.\" Jester courtesy of William Merritt Chase.

The Expedition has left Putre and is on the Avenue of the Volcáns. This is Arintica, 18,363 feet, below which the men conducted a hunt of the rhea, called suri by the Indians in Quechua. Courtesy Chile 2015.

These are the lesser rhea, or Darwin’s rhea, found at several locations in South America. They stand up to five feet tall and can weigh sixty pounds. A rhea on the run can reach up to 40 mph. Courtesy naturfoto.
Google image of Arintica on the left and the Salar de Surire, above, where the hunt took place. The Salar takes its name from the suri.
The Expedition camped near the thermal springs on the Salar. Courtesy turichile.
A scene somewhere on the Avenue of the Volcáns. Original 1931 photogravure by Atlantis-Verlag. R. Villarreal Collection.
Vicuña were in abundance on this part of the Avenue, and this is today's Chile National Vicuña Refuge. Courtesy of Bio Expedition.
This is the peak, Isluga, 18,208 feet. Near here the famous guanaco hunt took place. Courtesy turismochile.

An arquebus aimed using a fork rest. The hunt was led and conducted by Doña Inés! The arquebusier, Pedro Cisternas, loaded the gun, placed it in the fork rest, and La Doña fired it. Courtesy khanacademy.

The Expedition passed the Puchuldiza Geyser soon after the hunt. Captain Valdivia named it the "Sacred Fountain of our Lady". Courtesy chile tours and hotels.
In several more days, they came upon the Salar de Huasco. Courtesy of TravelChile.
The Huasco area is noted for its many alpaca and is now a Chilean Refuge for Alpacas. Courtesy pixabay.

This is the Salar de Coposa, with Irruputuncu, 16,939 feet, in the distance and is where horseman Mejia lost his life, as mentioned in the Third Letter. Those men who wished to pay their respects accompanied Father Perez to the grave site for brief prayers. Courtesy Andre Bonacin.
Atacama Desert scene. R. Villarreal collection.
A GOOGLE image of the Miño Volcán. It gives birth to the Loa River, which is visible in the center of the image. The Expedition will follow the river all the way to Calama.
The Loa springs from beneath Miño Volcán. Courtesy Ricardo Martini.
GOOGLE image of Chiu-Chiu and Calama, both situated along the Loa. Important events occurred in both towns.

Another GOOGLE image that shows the view east from Chiu-Chiu, with Atacama in the distance.  Captain Valdivia, Pedro, and Vicente rode there to welcome Francisco de Aguirre, Rodrigo de Quiroga, and the men they had recruited for the Expedition.  During their absence, Sancho de Hoz and his men entered the Spanish camp at Chiu-Chiu with the intent of killing Valdivia. Pedro tells what happened as a result.

A Google image of the desolate nature of the ground on the way from Calama to Atacama. I traveled this route with Chilean friends on the way to Atacama years ago and remember the forbidding nature of the ground, especially for those on foot.

This is the Quitor fortress today, which lies on the outskirts of San Pedro de Atacama. Several of the men visited it during their stay in the town. Courtesy of MJL.

Socaire was another small town the expedition passed. Courtesy Octavio Aldea.
Peine, still another small settlement. Courtesy donsimon2.

Our progress to the S was slowed early on the morning watch as unfavorable head winds blowing lustily at 39°15′S caused me to tack frequently 80 degrees to port and starboard as we beat before the wind. The book was translated and published in England by the editor and map publisher John Ogilby under the title, America, Being an Accurate Description of the New World (1671). One of the best-documented colonies was the expedition led by Prince Maurits of Nassau, who attempted to assemble an intellectual court in the New World. He brought with him a group of highly accomplished artists, mapmakers, and scientists to record the mysteries of Brazil. They included the celebrated painter Frans Post, and the astronomer George Markgraf, who produced the first serious study of the southern sky. R. Villarreal Collection.

De Mérida mentions passing an irrigation canal of a unique design after passing through Andahuaylillas. Perhaps it was similar to this one, located near their route of march. Courtesy: greenperuadventures.

As they neared Raqch'i, a temple and storage complex, de Mérida says that for some distance they followed an Inca road with a roadbed of finely shaped stones. Here is an example of one such road. Courtesy: commonswikimedia.

This is a photo of much of the Raqch'i complex that still survives today. It lies some 60 miles south of Cuzco and 50 miles north from Juliaca. To quote de Mérida from the Fourth Letter: \"Ancohualla described it thus: It served as a control point on the road between Cuzco and the towns to the south, such as Puno. A three mile perimeter wall encircled several Inca buildings. On the other side of this wall, an enclosure with eight rectangular buildings around a bright courtyard served as a welcoming place for travelers, with lodging for the people and stables for llamas. Anco continued that different areas served different functions – one to house troops, others for conducting religious festivities, still more were food and supply warehouses. The irrigated terraces on nearby hillsides testified to the agricultural richness of this place. A nearby warm spring fed water to a pool for cleansing the body. A large temple, one obviously for religious rites, completed the scene before us.\" Photo courtesy of: taringa.net.
This is part of the remaining walls of the Temple of Viracocha. Courtesy of peruadventuretours.
More Raqch'i walls. Courtesy of albumfotos.com.
More remnants of the Viracocha Temple. Somewhere within the Raqch'i complex, Gómez de Almagro was thrown from his horse and died of severe head wounds. Courtesy: Perutravel.
Original 1875 Wood Engraving of the Viracocha Temple amongst the Raqch'i ruins. Creator: Scribner, Armstrong, & Co. Artist: Edouard Riou. R. Villarreal Collection.

This village, called Hullaqa in de Mérida’s day (today known as Juliaca), the Expedition passed through in February, 1540. The natives made and marketed all types of warm clothing that the men bartered for to prepare for the coming cold days. Because of today's production of this clothing, it is also known as \"Sock City\" and \"Knitting City.\" It sits at 12,549 feet and has 225,000 citizens today. Courtesy of en.wikipedia
Caption: De Mérida called this \"a small, unremarkable village called Puno.\" Today it has 150,000 citizens and lies at 12,556 feet. Courtesy of Fotos de Puno.
The view of the eastern shore of Lake Titicaca from the towns on its western shores. Courtesy topvisitplaces.
Caption: A bustling market in today's Puno. Courtesy of Perutravel.

Ilave, at 12,621 feet and with 54,000 citizens, is south from Puno and bordered by the Ilave River, which the Expedition will follow to the west towards Putre for more than half the way. Courtesy of pano.com.
Another photo of Ilave. Courtesy of worldmapz.com.
A Google Earth image of the small village of Siraya.
Siraya, in de Mérida’s time and still so today, is a small village two days march west from Ilave. Its population is 900 inhabitants. Courtesy of joseluis379Pano.

Cachuma. West from Siraya lies the small settlement of Cachuma. Here is where de Merida mentions the Indian woman, Pilca Huaca. Doña Inéz had asked Valdivia for a medical assistant and Ancohualla suggested this woman, who happened to be an Inca princess. La Doña had already met her and was delighted that she would assist her. Courtesy of Jose Luis379.
Mazo Cruz. This is another small settlement, this one sits west from Cachuma. Courtesy of elcomercio.com.

Visviri. From this area, Lt. Montesinos saw the peak Taapaca to the west, which sits just outside Putre. Today, this town maintains the border station between Chile and Bolivia. Courtesy of Elias Munoz

Pukará de Copaquilla. This Inca fort/storage site is south from Visviri. Ancohualla said that the third Inca army to invade Chile passed this way and used this place to resupply themselves with food the local villagers had stored there. Courtesy of Wikimediacommons.

Pomerape, Parinacota. These two strato-volcanoes soon came in view. Pomerape, at 20,610 feet, is in front, with Parinacota, at 20,827 feet, to the left and behind it. They are known as the “Payachatas”, or fraternal twins in Aymara. Courtesy of Claudio Solari.
A Google Earth view of Pomerape and Parinacota, looking south.

Jurasi. This is the Jurasi thermal basin and springs which lie some six miles to the east of Putre. There are no active geysers today, but the thermal hot springs are a favorite with tourists. The Expedition stayed here for a night. Courtesy of Panoramio.
Taapaca. The mountain Taapaca, 19,230 feet high, sits a few miles to the east of Putre. Courtesy of Octavio Aldea.
Putre and Taapaca. Today's Putre. Courtesy of Travelblog.org.
One of the men from Tacna, Rodrigo Hidalgo, possessed jester skills. The Indians called him Qamchu, which in Quechua means \"one who makes people laugh.\" Jester courtesy of William Merritt Chase.

The Expedition has left Putre and is on the Avenue of the Volcáns. This is Arintica, 18,363 feet, below which the men conducted a hunt of the rhea, called suri by the Indians in Quechua. Courtesy Chile 2015.

These are the lesser rhea, or Darwin’s rhea, found at several locations in South America. They stand up to five feet tall and can weigh sixty pounds. A rhea on the run can reach up to 40 mph. Courtesy naturfoto.
Google image of Arintica on the left and the Salar de Surire, above, where the hunt took place. The Salar takes its name from the suri.
The Expedition camped near the thermal springs on the Salar. Courtesy turichile.
A scene somewhere on the Avenue of the Volcáns. Original 1931 photogravure by Atlantis-Verlag. R. Villarreal Collection.
Vicuña were in abundance on this part of the Avenue, and this is today's Chile National Vicuña Refuge. Courtesy of Bio Expedition.
This is the peak, Isluga, 18,208 feet. Near here the famous guanaco hunt took place. Courtesy turismochile.

An arquebus aimed using a fork rest. The hunt was led and conducted by Doña Inés! The arquebusier, Pedro Cisternas, loaded the gun, placed it in the fork rest, and La Doña fired it. Courtesy khanacademy.
A drawing of how the men lined up in support of Doña Inés for the guanaco hunt.  R. Villarreal Collection.
A lone guanaco on an Atacama salar. R. Villarreal Collection.
The Expedition passed the Puchuldiza Geyser soon after the hunt. Captain Valdivia named it the "Sacred Fountain of our Lady". Courtesy chile tours and hotels.
In several more days, they came upon the Salar de Huasco. Courtesy of TravelChile.
The Huasco area is noted for its many alpaca and is now a Chilean Refuge for Alpacas. Courtesy pixabay.

This is the Salar de Coposa, with Irruputuncu, 16,939 feet, in the distance and is where horseman Mejia lost his life, as mentioned in the Third Letter. Those men who wished to pay their respects accompanied Father Perez to the grave site for brief prayers. Courtesy Andre Bonacin.
Atacama Desert scene. R. Villarreal collection.
A GOOGLE image of the Miño Volcán. It gives birth to the Loa River, which is visible in the center of the image. The Expedition will follow the river all the way to Calama.
The Loa springs from beneath Miño Volcán. Courtesy Ricardo Martini.
GOOGLE image of Chiu-Chiu and Calama, both situated along the Loa. Important events occurred in both towns.

Another GOOGLE image that shows the view east from Chiu-Chiu, with Atacama in the distance.  Captain Valdivia, Pedro, and Vicente rode there to welcome Francisco de Aguirre, Rodrigo de Quiroga, and the men they had recruited for the Expedition.  During their absence, Sancho de Hoz and his men entered the Spanish camp at Chiu-Chiu with the intent of killing Valdivia. Pedro tells what happened as a result.

A Google image of the desolate nature of the ground on the way from Calama to Atacama. I traveled this route with Chilean friends on the way to Atacama years ago and remember the forbidding nature of the ground, especially for those on foot.
An example of a cactus outside Calama. Courtesy of atacamaphoto.

A nieves penitentes field between Calama and Atacama. The Expedition came across one such area after a recent snow storm and were able to replenish their water supplies by packing them into skin bags. Courtesy B. Tafreshi.
A penitentes field in the lower Atacama Desert. R. Villarreal Collection.

De Merida comments sometimes about the availability of ichu grass on the Atacama Desert, a favorite of the horses and the llamas. Here is a large concentration of it, again in the Atacama. R. Villarreal Collection.
This is the Quitor fortress today, which lies on the outskirts of San Pedro de Atacama. Several of the men visited it during their stay in the town. Courtesy of MJL.
This magnificent peak, Licancabur (19,420 feet), sits some fifteen miles to the northeast of Atacama and its beauty was remarked upon by the men. Courtesy of Summitpost.
This is the summit crater of Licancabor. The men DID NOT see this! Courtesy of A. Backer.
The walls of the Valley of the Moon, which sits some eight miles from Atacama. The men watched as the setting sun cast its beautiful rays across its sides. Courtesy of atacamaphoto.

The expedition passed by this town, Toconao, after leaving Atacama. Courtesy of wingsforscience.
Laguna Chaxa is near Toconao and is one of the lagunas in this area that make up the Chilean Flamingo Reserve. Courtesy RSABAT.
Socaire was another small town the expedition passed. Courtesy Octavio Aldea.
Peine, still another small settlement. Courtesy donsimon2.

Google image of Copayapu.  Valdivia and his men entered the town in August, 1540 and remained for several weeks before striking out for the southern part of Chile.

After leaving Isla Tolentino, the ships encountered hard winds.  Here is how Pastene described it in his journal:   \"September 12, 1544.  Our progress to the S was slowed early on the morning watch as unfavorable head winds blowing lustily at 39°15′S caused me to tack frequently 80 degrees to port and starboard as we beat before the wind.  At mid-day, we were in a full gale that blew with such violence that the San Pedro was almost driven forecastle under until I ordered the sails taken in, which eased the situation considerably.\"  Artist:  Lima de Freitas.

movies.title: Important Information
movies.note:
The movies in this section need an explanation. They are part of the content on the website for Clawing for the Stars: A Solo Climber in the Highest Andes. They are not directly related to the Almagro expedition. However, I have added them to the Chronicle site because they allow the reader to see some of the landscape and scenes the expedition encountered on their journey.

In the first movie for the First Letter, Parts L-M, the viewer will see Copiapo, travel the road to Laguna Santa Rosa, and visit the peak, Tres Cruces.

In the second movie, there are more scenes of Tres Cruces, a ride across the Great Plateau, Laguna Verde, and distant views of Ojos del Salado.

The movie for the Third Letter, Part V, is primarily a climb of Llullaillaco. The views here will permit readers of the interview with the Indian, Apani, (see Third Letter, Part V) to appreciate what the hut builders encountered when they were on the mountain more than 500 years ago.
